description: From Latin insertus, past participle of inserō, from in- +‎ serō (“join, bind together, connect, entwine, interweave”), ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *ser- (“to bind, put together, to line up”).

entries.meaning: A promotional or instructive leaflet inserted into a magazine, newspaper, tape or disk package, etc.
examples: This software can print compact disc inserts if you have the right size of paper.

entries.meaning: A mechanical component inserted into another.
(linguistics) An expression, such as "please" or an interjection, that may occur at various points in an utterance.
(genetics) A sequence of DNA inserted into another DNA molecule.
(television) A pre-recorded segment included as part of a live broadcast.
(film, television) A close-up shot used to draw attention to a particular element of a larger scene.
(audio effects) A plug-in that adds an effect to an audio track.

verbs.description: insert (third-person singular simple present inserts, present participle inserting, simple past and past participle inserted)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To put in between or into.
examples: In order to withdraw money from a cash machine, you have to insert your debit card.
To make your proof easier to understand, I recommend you insert a few more steps.
